title: Enya's Journey
roles: Game Design, Programming, UI, Level Design, Art & Animation
project_description: Enya's Journey is a turn RPG that blends pixel-art characters with modeled environments, created for a Game Programming school project over two months by a five-person team as a fantasy adventure built around fire. The player makes use of various fire spells with different utility with 6 classes they can freely swap between, managing heat in combat, and expending it strategically to do massive damage without overheating. My teammates contributed music, narrative writing, sprite creation, pixel art animation, and story programming.
project_contributions: Authored the class document for programming and the Game Design document.
Programmed the battle system, covering stats, turn flow, spells, enemy encounters, etc.
Designed the RPG systems from class structure, spells, and items.
Designed and decorated the entire map, and created textures for terrain and water.
Created all custom shaders in Shader Graph for spell effects and the clouds.
Made all spell effects and fire effects in Visual Effects Graph.
Implemented and designed all the UI, excluding the dialogue system.
highlight: Working on Enya's Journey was significant to me as an avid fan of RPGs. This project was a testament to my growth as a developer, where I truly felt like I crested the hill where I spent more time creating than learning and an oppurtunity to show true dedication to a single project, 8 or more hours a day consistently. As I reflect it also showed me my limits, whether it be code and the need for proper design patterns, or design and the need to make sure that what I add solves a problem, or that I need to rely on teammates more. Despite how the time on the project was spent you could say it's where I learned the most about game development.

title: Baby Steps
tagline: Baby's are a Joy, Baby's are a Terror.
project_description: Baby Steps is a VR game where players care for a baby by fulfilling its needs such as being held, fed, and entertained over a 4.5-minute session. The game was created as part of a final project for IMDM290 by a six-person team. It focuses on multitasking gameplay inspired by titles like Overcooked and Tattletail. The game features a cartoon-style shader, various animations, and a fully modeled in-game environment.
project_contributions: Developed the baby AI, with various states such as Idle, Roaming, and Hungry.
Implemented the cel-shading shader using HLSL and wrote code to apply reverse hull technique onto objects.
Programmed interactions, such as the cooking process and feeding mechanics.
highlight: One of the most rewarding parts was demystifying the render pipeline. By hooking into it and injecting custom render information, I gained a deeper understanding of how rendering works. For me this porject was another step in chipping away at the 'untouchable' parts of game development, stepping away from tutorial land.

title: Taxes and Tenacity
project_description: A roguelite game that weaves RPG elements with a life-and-tax system, created during a two-week game jam by a duo. In this world, the player embarks on dungeon expeditions to collect gold from defeated monsters, facing a looming tax deadline. Successfully paying your taxes means earning extra lives; failure leads to losing them all. My partner contributed by crafting the stages, the connecting map, and designing the floor bosses' attacks.
project_contributions: programmed player, camera movement, stats and enemy ai.
Developed the enemy waves on each of the nodes
Balanced the in-game economy for upgrades and boosts.
Designed the tax based lives system.
highlight: Reflecting on the project, the aspect that fills me with the most pride are the character controls. One of the focuses and ideas behind this project was simplifying things down, focusing in on content and feel. The three-hit sword animation has a satisfying timing to it. I find that moving around has the simple fun to it that I was looking for in ways that some previous projects lacked. That said, this game is also a bit even-keeled—one thing I wanted to expand upon in the future is those moments of excitement.

title: Silent Codes
roles: Game Design, Graphics Programming, UI Design
project_description: An interactive two-player puzzle game developed over a two-week period, blending traditional escape room elements with digital puzzle-solving. Player 1 navigates a memory puzzle minigame to extract crucial code pieces, while Player 2 uses a physical cipher to decode the information. The game intensifies with the presence of a Boss character, forcing both players to remain quiet and avoid detection.
project_contributions: Wrote a CRT shader in HLSL for visual effects.
Created the minigame for obtaining code pieces.
Came up with the busy work task for making the boss think you are working.
highlight: For me this project was definitely a about implementing the CRT effect it gave me the chance to start learning HLSL, and see how to apply shaders through screenspace, target parts of the renderpipeline and more. Which became profoundly helpful in later projects, particularly as when I took a dive into Stylized PBR with a another one of my games Baby Steps.

title: Got Steam, Punk?
tagline: A Comedic Adventure on the High Seas.
project_description: Developed during a game jam by a seven-member team, this game combines humor with a high-seas adventure on the world's most advanced, barely seaworthy steamship. Playing as a crew member, the goal is to keep the ship afloat by completing various repair tasks. The player is handed a steam-powered grappling hook to navigate the ship quickly, adding a dynamic element to the gameplay. The game features a cartoonish art style and a lighthearted narrative.
project_contributions: Designed the ship’s layout and repair task sequence.
Implemented the steam-powered grappling hook mechanics and the slide.
Took the ship from it's blockout to the finished layout.
Created a class document for the game's code.
highlight: On Got Steam, Punk?, the real task was the interior of the ship—making it detailed and believable. Evan's solid models set the foundation, and together with Jeremy, we added some humor into the mix with the signs around the ship. My job was to figure out the best spots for grappling points for players to navigate quickly, keeping the gameplay smooth and engaging. I spent a good deal of time ensuring that every piece of the ship was placed just right, drawing from real-life references to get that authentic steamship feel.

title: Lab Bat
tagline: Fly and Deliver in a Bat's World.
project_description: Lab Bat is a puzzle platformer inspired by flash game era developed over a three-day game jam. Based on the odd World War II story where they tested using bats as a way to deliver bomvs. In this game, the protagonist, a bat who originally could not fly, navigates a facility filled with hazards to deliver a bomb to its destination in exchange for flight. The player controls the bat's movement to solve puzzles delivering the bomb to the end of the level while avoiding challenges like acid pools and lasers.
project_contributions: Designed all 6 puzzle levels, the players moveset and the level hazards.
Placed the level assets and contributed to pixel art like the ooze containers.
Designed and implemented the UI, including the intro animation.
highlight: Within Lab Bat, the fifth level stands out as my personal best. It's where the game starts to truly challenge the player's problem-solving skills. The setup involves placing the crate onto a moving platform, followed by the bomb. Most players instinctively cling to the bomb due to this order, only to find that the crate then obstructs the intended path. I found that the realization that they need to hold onto the crate instead was a satisfying ah-hah moment from watching players in this level.

title: Scale the Beast
project_description: Scale the Beast is an action platformer developed during the GMTK Game Jam 2024 in just 4 days. Working with the same team Taxes and Tenacity. We imagined an action platformer where you scale a dragon so large that it doesn't fit onto the screen. The player scales the dragon chipping away at it's week points, and dealing with the various hazards of it's body.
project_contributions: Implemented the character controller, animation and attack system.
Implemented the event based progression system.
Designed the level placing the assets for the main level was split 50/50.
Created the intro scene featuring a dramatic dragon entrance.
highlight: One of the highlights of working on Scale the Beast was crafting the intro scene. The moment when the dragon comes down and the game transitions to the title screen created a powerful and memorable impact for players. Seeing their reactions made all the effort worthwhile. The games architecture emphasizes flexibility and maintainability. I adopted an event-driven approach where systems communicate through signals rather than direct dependencies. Using patterns inspired by the Observer and Component designs. The progression through the level and the traps are largely defined by events, allowing us to quickly setup level progression logic and make traps responsive to the player.

title: Blades on Ice
tagline: Teams are made on the ice.
project_description: Blades on Ice is a cooperative figure skating game where two players embody a pair ice dancing team. Switch between Practice, Performance, and Story Mode as you master iconic dance elements like twizzles, spins, and lifts. Gameplay blends rhythm timing, synchronized movement, and expressive presentation to capture the artistry of ice dance. Each performance is graded on musicality, connection, and precision.
project_contributions: Authored the Game Design document, and made documentation for various tools.
Designed the skating mechanics and the overall gameplay loop.
Implemented a Stack-based UI system to reduce dependencies.
Implemented a data first approach to character stats, progression and routines and practice.
Programmed the input bufffering system for the motion inputs.
Created effects to exentuate the ice skating like the burst when a crossover is performed.
highlight: This is my first real Unreal project ignoring prototpes. Being the longest I've worked on a project since my first attemp in junior year high school, and really tested myself as designer working in a genere outside of my general interest on a topic I initially knew little about and as a developer on my ability to manage scope and build maintainable systems. I've learned a lot about Unreal, C++, and game design in general. It was my first attempt at data-driven design, which I used to make creating varied practice routines and other parts of the content centralized and accessible to non-programmers.
